key_points: Kamala Harris was sworn in as vice president of the United States, marking several historical firsts including the first woman, first Black person, and first Asian American in the role.
Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the first woman of color on the Supreme Court, administered the oath to Harris.
Harris used two Bibles for the swearing-in ceremony, one belonging to family friend Regina Shelton and the other once owned by the late Justice Thurgood Marshall.
This moment was particularly significant for Harris, who reflected on her mother and the people counting on their leadership.
Harris often cites her mother, Shyamala Gopalan Harris, in her speeches, emphasizing the importance of paving the way for others.
Sen. Amy Klobuchar highlighted the significance of Harris's role for children worldwide, showing them that 'anything and everything is possible.'
The vice presidential oath, shared with that taken by members of Congress, focuses on defending the Constitution and faithfully discharging the duties of the office.
Harris is also the first graduate of a historically Black college and the first member of a Black sorority to become vice president.
Harris' role as vice president breaks significant gender and racial barriers in U.S. politics.
The ceremony employed Bibles with personal and historical significance, highlighting both personal journeys and broader social progress.
